items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: City Dismisses Talk of a Willets Point Casino
items.abstract: Speculation has been rampant that a gambling center would be set up in Willets Point, but the Bloomberg administration says it is not going to happen.

items.title: Vital City Revenue, Lost in the Fine Print
items.abstract: Invisible real-estate deals include the city comptroller’s assertion that the city land under the Marriott Marquis hotel was sold far too cheaply.

items.title: A South Korean City Full of Food, History and Bargains
items.abstract: I spend my life looking for places like Jeonju, a city barely known to Western travelers. It’s a paradise for both lovers of Korean food and cheap prices.

items.title: 36 Hours in Panama City Beach, Fla.
items.abstract: Peer beyond the tattoo parlors and sweaty spring breakers and you’ll find everything from sugary sands to a farmers’ market in this Emerald Coast town.

items.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
items.abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.

items.title: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
items.abstract: The announcement, which also noted that just over 78 percent of state students earned a diploma, came as state officials met to consider changes in graduation requirements.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Makes New York City’s Fiscal Case to a Wary Legislature
items.abstract: The mayor asked for state funding for city public housing and homelessness prevention programs, while some lawmakers argued that the city should receive less help from Albany.

items.title: Shooting at Seattle Tent City Coincides With Mayor’s Homelessness Speech
items.abstract: Five people are shot, two of them fatally, in what the city authorities are calling a target attack, possibly linked to low-level drug activity.

items.title: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
items.abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which debuts on Tuesday, is the 10th ballet Mr. Peck has choreographed for the company he joined in 2007.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: Success of Los Angeles Teachers Strike Rocks Charter Schools, and a Rich Supporter
items.abstract: Supporters of charter schools are back on their heels in Los Angeles and across the country after a wave of mass teacher walkouts.

items.title: Nursing Homes Are Closing Across Rural America, Scattering Residents
items.abstract: As financial pressures have forced scores of small-town nursing homes to shut down, their residents often must relocate far from their families to find care.

items.title: Brazen Shooting Traumatizes Dutch City, Three Days After Christchurch Killings
items.abstract: Dutch authorities were looking into multiple possible motives for the shooting, which wounded five people.

items.title: Deer Park Fire: Benzene in Texas City’s Air Briefly Forces Everyone Inside
items.abstract: Officials had told residents to stay indoors for the second time in a week after a large chemical fire erupted at a storage tank on Sunday.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: How New York City’s Hospitals Withstood the Omicron Surge
items.abstract: The highly contagious coronavirus variant stretched the city’s health care system to the breaking point, but not past it.

items.title: How Josh Mandel, Son of Suburban Ohio, Became a Right-Wing Warrior
items.abstract: The Senate candidate was a rising Republican when he abandoned his moderate roots. Now, those who have watched his transformation wonder if his rhetoric reflects who he really is.

items.title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
items.abstract: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.

items.title: Anxiety Grows in Odessa as Russians Advance in Southern Ukraine
items.abstract: Residents of Odessa, Ukraine’s critical port on the Black Sea, are bracing as Russian naval and ground forces approach. “Every day they make it seem like today is the day,” the mayor said.
